newsitem.title: USA: US stocks waiting game seen ending with job report.
newsitem.headline: US stocks waiting game seen ending with job report.

text.p: Wall Street stocks will see their brief waiting game draw to a close on Friday, with release of the key September U.S. payrolls report.
On Thursday, markets quieted considerably, adopting a cautious tone ahead of the closely watched jobs data, which markets view as an important leading inflation indicator.
"The market went from frothy to flat" as release of the report neared, said Alan Ackerman, market strategist at Fahnestock & Co, "so some sort of bounce is likely to result from the report."
Economists surveyed by Reuters forecast a 166,000 rise in non-farm payrolls in September after a 250,000 increase in August.
The unemployment rate is expected to edge up to 5.2 percent from 5.1 percent and average hourly wage growth is seen dipping to 0.2 percent from a 0.5 percent rate in August.
"The headline number will be the payrolls," said Larry Wachtel, market analyst at Prudential Securities. "But the composition of wages paid will also be watched carefully."
"Anything above 200,000 (in payrolls) would be hurtful," he said, adding that a payrolls figure below 125,000 would likely offer enough incentive for markets to rally.
In Toyko, stocks declined ahead of the U.S. jobs data. The Nikkei 225 index slid 183 points to 21,148.
In London, U.S. stocks also eased ahead of the report. The FTSE 100 fell 15.5 points to 3984.5.
The dollar was firm in Tokyo, holding near 111.5 yen, and was steady in European activity at just above 1.53 marks.
U.S. Treasuries were firm in early activity. The benchmark 30-year bond rose 9/32 to push its yield down to 6.82 percent.
S&P 500 index futures were unchanged at 697.7.
The New York Times Marketplace column reports that Wall Street analysts are pleased with Hilton Hotels Corp's recent round of acquisitions and deals.
The Wall Street Journal's Heard on the Street column notes that investors have been bidding up shares in Nabsico Holdings Corp even as analysts have been trimming earnings estimates.
